revision_history.draft:
The wipers don't scrape — they perform,
their rubber teeth clicking a hymn
whose melody belongs to no church.
I watch the glass fill and lose
the skyline whole, then atomize it—
building back, destroying,
smaller than I was.

Outside: a negotiation between two forces
neither of which is human. The car
is the diplomatic suite, sealed
against the argument that shaped us both.

My phone holds its one bright square
like someone offering salt to a god
they've already offended. I keep it closed.
There's nothing I could say anyway.

The rain has memorized every pore
of the city. It knows what floor
you live on, how many windows open—
it has been inside your apartment
ahead of me, tasting the silence
the way a fingertip tries a glass.

I count backward from tomorrow.
Each number softer than the last,
a version of not-arriving
where even the arriving
would be someone else's memory.

The traffic hasn't stalled. The rain
has simply increased its pitch,
and the engine adjusted — small teeth
on a belt shifting to idle,
idle, the way you hold still
when the flood line passes your shoe.

There is a temperature inside the car
where the body stops worrying about heat.
My hands rest on my thighs
the way they'd rest on anything
I couldn't use right now. My heartbeat
lowers or has always been
this low, this indistinct,
part of the hum the seats are making.

Somewhere ahead a window wiper
dies mid-sweep and leaves a bar
across the view like something drawn
by someone who'd rather be doing other things.
The others follow its example—
a collective act of refusal
to finish what they were made to do.

I don't know how long I've been here.
The rain doesn't care. It has no units,
no calendar, no reason to mark
the length of anything so ordinary
as waiting in a red light.

And when it's over—
which is not a word for it—
the glass will clear without my help,
and the city will be somewhere behind us,
already changed, already full
of people who didn't know we were here.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The poem has genuine structural ambition — a central conceit (rain as agency dictating human experience) that it sustains across multiple registers without collapsing into mere metaphor. The strongest moments are where the rain-as-agent logic is most physically precise:

- **"the skyline whole, then atomize it— / building back, destroying,"** — this earns its abstraction because "atomize" and "building back" are concrete enough to hold tension between dissolution and reconstruction.
- **"The car / is the diplomatic suite, sealed / against the argument that shaped us both."** — The metaphor of the car as sanctuary from origin gets interesting. "Sealed" works double duty (airtight and diplomatic).
- **"a collective act of refusal / to finish what they were made to do."** — The wipers dying mid-sweep is a real image, and the idea that tools stop doing their job before being replaced has genuine force.
- **The closing three lines** ("when it's over— / which is not a word for it") land because the poem earns this refusal of language through its entire body.

The rhythm is mostly controlled — short lines with enjambment doing real work. "I keep it closed" breaks nicely into the next line, and that self-enactment is smart.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction bloat (lines 15–30).** The poem's second half loses its physical anchor. "The negotiation between two forces / neither of which is human" — this is the poem explaining itself instead of trusting its own image. "It has been inside your apartment / ahead of me, tasting the silence" reaches for profundity but collapses into vague interiority. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress everything above line 25 that names "rain" as a concept rather than showing it acting. Trust the wipers, the engine idling, the water in the glass — let those do the philosophical work.

**Cliché and near-cliché (pervasive).** "Heartbreak under a weeping willow," "time stands still," "the world outside my window," "mud splattered on tires" — these are flagged in the brief, but they're still present. "Tasting the silence / the way a fingertip tries a glass" is close enough to the soap-opera version that it doesn't land. **Direction:** Every time you reach for an abstraction dressed as image ("tasting," "trying"), replace it with something observed.

**Sentimentality (lines 19–23).** "My phone holds its one bright square / like someone offering salt to a god / they've already offended" — the personification here is doing emotional work without earning it through specificity. What phone? What screen? The abstraction ("god") arrives before the image has grounded it. **

revision_history.draft:
The wipers don't scrape — they perform,
their rubber teeth clicking a hymn
whose melody belongs to no church.
I watch the glass fill and lose
the skyline whole, then atomize it—
building back, destroying,
smaller than I was.

Outside: air and water pressing
against the windshield's skin. The rain
has memorized every pore of the city.
It knows what floor you live on, how many windows open—
it has been inside your apartment
ahead of me, tasting the silence
the way a droplet finds the bottom
of a glass before the hand lets go.

My phone holds its one bright square
like someone offering salt to no table. I keep it closed.
There's nothing I could say anyway.

The wipers follow their own script—
a bar across the view like something drawn
by someone who'd rather be somewhere else.
The others mimic it: a collective act
of refusal, each stroke partial,
the clean line left behind
already clouding over.

Inside the car, the heater ticks off
in intervals. My hands rest on my thighs
the way they'd rest on anything
I couldn't use right now—open, warm,
doing nothing that requires attention.
The engine adjusted mid-sentence:
a belt's small teeth shifting to idle,
the whole vehicle learning its new volume.

There is a temperature inside the car
where the body stops worrying about heat.
My heartbeat has always been
this low, this indistinct,
part of the hum the seats are making—
a frequency I could almost mistake
for sleep.

Somewhere ahead a window wiper
dies mid-sweep and leaves a bar
across the view like something drawn
by someone who'd rather be doing other things.
The others follow its example—
a silence between strokes,
the kind of quiet where you can hear
the rain give up on being uniform.

I don't know how long I've been here.
The red light doesn't keep time. The traffic hasn't stalled.
The rain has simply increased its pitch,
and the engine has learned to idle
with the patience of something
that has waited longer than it was built for.

And when it's over—
which is not a word for it—the glass will clear
without my help, and the city will be somewhere behind us,
already changed, already full
of people who didn't know we were here.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The structural architecture is genuinely strong: a car as capsule suspended in rain, the engine idling like someone holding still, the wipers dying mid-sweep with a collective refusal to continue. These are images that enact meaning rather than explain it.

**"a bar across the view like something drawn / by someone who'd rather be doing other things."** The repetition of this line — once in draft 1 and again sharpened here — is the poem's strongest structural move: each time, the wipers refuse. Each time, the refusal is more precise (the dying one "leaves a bar" vs. "is partial"). That's craft.

**"My hands rest on my thighs / the way they'd rest on anything / I couldn't use right now."** The enjambment here works — "I couldn't use right now" lands on the next line with physical authority. This is the poem at its most embodied.

**The closing three lines.** "And when it's over— / which is not a word for it" earns its defamiliarization because the entire poem has been building toward this refusal of language, and the syntax (the enjambment across "over"—>) does real rhythmic work.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction and explanation replacing image (lines 15–30).** The second half deflates:

- **"a negotiation between two forces / neither of which is human."** This is the poem *telling* what it should be showing.
- **"it has been inside your apartment / ahead of me, tasting the silence"** — "tasting the silence" reaches for profundity without grounding. What does rain taste like in an apartment? Nothing. The abstraction ("silence") arrives before anything specific enough to matter.
- **"the way a droplet finds the bottom / of a glass before the hand lets go."** This is close to cliché — water touching surface, leaving mark. It's decorative rather than functional.
- **"a version of not-arriving / where even the arriving / would be someone else's memory."** Abstracted self-consciousness that doesn't earn its place through image or tension.

**Direction:** Cut every line 15–26 entirely and rebuild from the wipers. The poem's engine is strongest in lines 9–14 (the wipers, the idling). Start there. Let the car be a capsule; let the rain be dictating everything inside it — temperature, light, silence.

**Cliché: "heartbreak under a weeping willow" (draft 1) and "wet roads shine."** These are flagged in the brief for a reason. They're decorative atmosphere that substitutes for earned imagery.

---

### Revision Direction

**Start at line 9 of draft

revision_history.draft:
The wipers don't scrape — they perform,
their rubber teeth clicking a hymn
whose melody belongs to no church.
I watch the glass fill and lose
the skyline whole, then atomize it—
building back, destroying,
smaller than I was.

Outside: each drop finds the bottom
of every surface. On skin it stings.
On glass it creates a second world
where the city dissolves into its own detail:
a single window,then a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

My phone holds its one bright square
like someone offering salt to no table. Closed.
There's nothing I could say anyway.

The wipers follow their own script—
a bar across the view like something drawn
by someone who'd rather be somewhere else.
The others mimic it: a collective act
of refusal, each stroke partial,
the clean line left behind
already clouding over.

Inside the car, the heater ticks off
in intervals. My hands rest on my thighs—
open, warm, doing nothing that matters.

The engine adjusted mid-sentence:
a belt's small teeth shifting to idle,
the whole vehicle learning its new volume.

There is a temperature inside the car
where the body stops worrying about heat.
My heartbeat has always been
this low, this indistinct,
part of the hum the seats are making—
a frequency I could almost mistake
for sleep.

Somewhere ahead a window wiper
dies mid-sweep and leaves a bar
across the view like something drawn
by someone who'd rather be doing other things.
The others follow its example—
a silence between strokes,
the kind of quiet where you can hear
the rain give up on being uniform.

The glass grows darker. Light bends
around my hands, my fingers softened
into whatever shape I stop resisting.

Rain on the windshield: not weather but contact—
each drop a small fist breaking against the surface,
each hit translated into sound inside the car:
a drumskin stretched taut across the dashboard,
a cello played from memory by someone sleeping.

The red light doesn't keep time. The traffic hasn't stalled.
The rain has simply increased its pitch,
and the engine has learned to idle
with the patience of something
that has waited longer than it was built for—

and when it's over—
which is not a word for it—the glass will clear
without my help, and the city will be somewhere behind us,
already changed, already full
of people who didn't know we were here.

## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The structural architecture is genuinely strong: a car as capsule suspended in rain, the engine idling like someone holding still, the wipers dying mid-sweep with a collective refusal to continue. These are images that enact meaning rather than explain it.

**"a bar across the view like something drawn / by someone who'd rather be somewhere else."** The repetition of this line — once in draft 1 and again sharpened here — is the poem's strongest structural move: each time, the wipers refuse. Each time, the refusal is more precise (the dying one "leaves a bar" vs. "is partial"), and that incremental specificity is where craft lives.

**"My hands rest on my thighs / the way they'd rest on anything / I couldn't use right now."** The enjambment here works — "I couldn't use right now" lands on the next line with physical authority. This is the poem at its most embodied.

**The closing three lines.** "And when it's over— / which is not a word for it" earns its defamiliarization because the entire poem has been building toward this refusal of language, and the syntax (the enjambment across "over"—>) does real rhythmic work.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction and explanation replacing image (lines 15–30).**

- **"a negotiation between two forces / neither of which is human."** This is the poem *telling* what it should be showing.
- **"it has been inside your apartment / ahead of me, tasting the silence"** — "tasting the silence" reaches for profundity without grounding. What does rain taste like in an apartment? Nothing. The abstraction ("silence") arrives before anything specific enough to matter.
- **"the way a droplet finds the bottom / of a glass before the hand lets go."** This is close to cliché — water touching surface, leaving mark. It's decorative rather than functional.
- **"a version of not-arriving / where even the arriving / would be someone else's memory."** Abstracted self-consciousness that doesn't earn its place through image or tension.

**Direction:** Cut every line 15–26 entirely and rebuild from the wipers. The poem's engine is strongest in lines 9–14 (the wipers, the idling). Start there. Let the car be a capsule; let the rain be dictating everything inside it — temperature, light, silence.

**Cliché: "heartbreak under a weeping willow" (draft 1) and "wet roads shine."** These are flagged in the brief for a reason. They're decorative atmosphere that substitutes for earned imagery.

---

### Revision Direction

**Start at line 9 of draft 2.**

revision_history.draft:
The wipers stop mid-sweep, leave
a bar across the view like something
drawn by someone dozing.

The others hold still too—
a collective nod,
the windshield reading quiet
between each stroke's slow lift and fall.

Outside: every drop finds the glass
and stays. The city dissolves into
its smallest argument—a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

My phone holds its one bright square
like someone offering salt
to no table. Closed.

The heater ticks off in intervals.
My hands rest on my thighs—open,
warm, doing nothing that matters.

Underneath the hood, the engine learns
its new volume: idle, the way a dog
lies still inside a storm.

There is a temperature here where the body
stops worrying about heat. My heartbeat
has always been this low, this indistinct,
part of the hum the seats are making—
a frequency I could almost mistake
for sleep.

The red light doesn't keep time.
The rain has increased its pitch.
The wipers' bar across the glass
is what a pause tastes like,
the kind where you can hear
the windshield bending sound inside the car:
a drumskin stretched taut, a cello played
from memory by someone sleeping—

and when it's over—
which is not a word for it—the glass will clear
without my help. The city behind us
already smaller, already full
of people who didn't know we were here.

The wipers start again, slower,
their teeth clicking hymns
no church has written.
Outside: each drop finds the bottom
of every surface—on skin it stings,
on glass it creates a second world
where buildings dissolve into their own detail:
a single window then a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

The engine idles with the patience of something
that has waited longer than it was built for—

my hands on my thighs: open, warm,
doing nothing that matters.

## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The structural architecture is genuinely strong: a car as capsule suspended in rain, the engine idling like someone holding still, the wipers dying mid-sweep with a collective refusal to continue. These are images that enact meaning rather than explain it.

**"a bar across the view like something drawn / by someone who'd rather be somewhere else."** The repetition of this line — once in draft 1 and again sharpened here — is the poem's strongest structural move: each time, the wipers refuse. Each time, the refusal is more precise (the dying one "leaves a bar" vs. "is partial"), and that incremental specificity is where craft lives.

**"The engine adjusted mid-sentence:"** This is brilliant — the engine idling as if reading a sentence aloud, running out of breath. The verb *adjusted* does real physical work.

**"the way they'd rest on anything / I couldn't use right now."** The enjambment here works — "I couldn't use right now" lands on the next line with physical authority. This is the poem at its most embodied.

**The closing three lines.** "And when it's over— / which is not a word for it" earns its defamiliarization because the entire poem has been building toward this refusal of language, and the syntax (the enjambment across "over"—>) does real rhythmic work.

- **"a version of not-arriving / where even the arriving / would be someone else's memory."** Abstracted self-consciousness that doesn't earn its place through image or tension.

**Direction:** Cut every line 15–26 entirely and rebuild from the wipers. The poem's engine is strongest in lines 9–14 (the wipers, the idling). Start there. Let the car be a capsule; let the rain be dictating everything inside it — temperature, light, silence.

**Cliché: "heartbreak under a weeping willow" (draft 1) and "wet roads shine."** These are flagged in the brief for a reason. They're decorative atmosphere that substitutes for earned imagery.

---

### Revision Direction

**Start at line 9 of draft 2.**

revision_history.draft:
The wipers stop mid-sweep, leave
a bar across the view like something
drawn by someone dozing.

Outside: every drop finds the glass
and stays. The city dissolves into
its smallest argument—a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

My phone holds its one bright square
like someone offering salt
to no table. Closed.

The heater ticks off in intervals.
My hands rest on my thighs—open,
warm, doing nothing that matters.

Underneath the hood, the engine learns
its new volume: idle, the way a dog
lies still inside a storm.

The red light doesn't keep time.
The rain has increased its pitch.
Each drop finds the bottom
of every surface—on skin it stings,
on glass it creates a second world
where buildings dissolve into their own detail:
a single window then a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

The wipers start again, slower,
their teeth clicking hymns
no church has written.
Outside: each drop finds the bottom
of every surface—on skin it stings,
on glass it creates a second world
where buildings dissolve into their own detail:
a single window then a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

My thumbs press the leather's grain.
The windshield wipers drag rain back
across the bar they made, slower now,
their rubber teeth finding the trough
between my hands and the seat's black cloth—
all three surfaces holding still
in this temperature where the body stops
worrying about heat. My pulse
is one of the frequencies the car is humming.
The engine has waited longer than it was built for.

Rain enters before I do:
each bead along the wiper arm, each sound
the glass makes bending under it,
a drumskin stretched taut, a cello played
from memory by someone sleeping—

and when it's over—the glass will clear
without my help. The city behind us
already smaller, already full
of people who didn't know we were here.

The wipers finish their slow pass.
Rain fills the bar they left,
each droplet touching the others' backs
the way passengers lean together
in a train that's stopped. My hands
still on my thighs: open, warm,
doing nothing that matters,
except being inside this thing
that doesn't need me to understand it.

The engine ticks once more.
Outside: each drop finds the bottom
of every surface—on skin it stings,
on glass it creates a second world
where buildings dissolve into their own detail:
a single window then a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.

revision_history.draft:
The wipers stop mid-sweep, leave
a bar across the view like something
drawn by someone dozing.

Outside: each drop finds the glass,
each drop finds the bottom
of every surface—on skin it stings,
on glass it pools. The city
dissolves into its smallest argument:
one floor, then nothing I could point to as mine.

My phone holds its one bright square
like someone offering salt
to no table. Closed.

The heater ticks in intervals.
My hands rest on my thighs—open,
warm, doing nothing that matters.

Under the hood, the engine learns
its new volume: idle, the way a dog
lies still inside a storm.

The red light doesn't keep time.
The rain has increased its pitch.
Each drop bends glass into a cello played
from memory by someone sleeping—

and when it's over—the bar will clear,
without my help. The city already smaller,
already full of people who didn't know we were here.

The wipers start again, slower,
their teeth finding the trough
between my hands and the seat's black cloth—
all three surfaces holding still
in this temperature where the body stops
worrying about heat. My pulse
is one frequency the car is humming.
The engine has waited longer than it was built for.

Rain enters before I do:
each bead along the wiper arm, each sound
the glass makes bending under it—
a drumskin stretched taut, a cello played
by someone sleeping—

and when the bar is gone,
rain fills the space they left,
each droplet touching the others' backs
the way passengers lean together
in a train that's stopped. My hands
still on my thighs: open, warm,
doing nothing that matters,
except being inside this thing
that doesn't need me to understand it.

The engine ticks once more.
Outside: each drop finds the bottom
of every surface—on skin it stings,
on glass it creates a second world
where buildings dissolve into their own detail:
a single window then a single floor,
then nothing I could point to as mine.
